video.title: 🎮 Easy JavaScript Game Development with Kaboom.js (Mario, Zelda, and Space Invaders) - Full Course
video.description:
Learn how use JavaScript and Kaboom.js to create three classic video games. You will create games similar to Space Invaders, Super Mario Bros. and Legend of Zelda. Kaboom.js makes makes it easier and quicker to create games.

✏️ This course was developed by Ania Kubów. Check out her channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/AniaKubów

⭐️ Code ⭐️
🔗 Space Invaders: https://replit.com/@AniaKubow/Kaboomjs-Space-Invaders
🔗 Mario: https://replit.com/@AniaKubow/Kaboomjs-Mario
🔗 Zelda: https://replit.com/@AniaKubow/Kaboomjs-Zelda

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:04:12) The basics
⌨️ (0:16:47) Space Invaders
⌨️ (0:47:32) Mario
⌨️ (1:45:15) Zelda
⌨️ (2:46:39) Sharing to the Replit App Store
⌨️ (2:48:03) Using any Code Editor

🎉 Thanks to Replit for providing a grant that made this course possible.

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Larry DeGraw
topLevelComment.text: Is there a support forum for Kaboom or Replit - I'm not sure what this issue is? It seems this tutorial is already out of date because I've ran into several issues which I've had to change in the code. Now I'm adding the "collides" function and when I run it's giving me "Error: h._checkCollisions is not a function". Nothing comes up in Google for that error.

replies.author: Jesús Jiménez
replies.text: Seems this tutorial is already out of date.

topLevelComment.author: Larry DeGraw
topLevelComment.text: I'm following along. I'm at about 22:00 where we run the level screen. I'm getting ERROR: level symbol def must be a function returning a component list. I Google for that message and get nothing. I have the code correct. Is that a result of the current Kaboom version?

replies.author: iqu10timesaday
replies.text: Thanks guys! This was driving me nuts.

replies.author: D
replies.text: @Larry DeGraw lol i found the answer right after replying to u. Thankx tho, I was struggling with this for the longest time

replies.author: Larry DeGraw
replies.text: @D In the addLevel array, where you define what each character on the map is, you have to add () => between the colon and the opening bracket. Eg... '^' : () => [sprite('space-invader')]. Later on, I discovered you have to add this to each of those sprite properties: area() - in order for collides() to work.

replies.author: D
replies.text:
Edit: I just found the answer. It's a formatting issue. You have to load the sprite first seperatly. Then, instead of putting 
"^" : [sprite("space invader")]
you have to do

"^": () => [
        sprite("space invader"),
    ],

topLevelComment.author: Giancarlo Andre Bravo Abanto
topLevelComment.text: as a game dev for years I see, theres some misunderstanding what a game framework is: will do all the logic and the work for you. So if you want to do the same thing in other languages like C++ you will be starting from zero again and again. better is use no framework and get all the logic by yourself

replies.author: Giancarlo Andre Bravo Abanto
replies.text: @Gonçalo Teixeira you mentioned for C++. OpenGL is the choose. If you want to gain knowledge quickly you should use JavaScript and make your animations in canvas element although most of the functions are the same

replies.author: tabundo001
replies.text:
Okay i found one solution, in case you're having the same issue, you can fix it this way:

Create this:

const timeBig = 6


Then on biggify()

timer = timeBig

That's it. Not sure if it's the kaboom version but no way my code knew that the argument I was passing iside player.biggify() was meant for 'time', so you can just do it manually like I did I think it looks easier too to have the constant somewhere else with other constants.

topLevelComment.author: stateside_heavy

Everything inside the initial kaboom function works in game.js (I get a black fullscreen when i copy the path and open my index.html in a browser), but none of the sprites. Is there an extra step for using VS Code or any code editor other than Replit? It seems to me like Replit takes care of a lot of stuff behind-the-scenes, that in VS Code I would need to write out.  Could you please share what it is I'm missing? (besides a more intelligent brain)

topLevelComment.author: veeeeeeee
topLevelComment.text: Anyone else having a weird bug where the last row of invaders in Space Invaders keeps moving irregularly in comparison to the previous rows? Sometimes, they do go beyond the walls and that messes up the game.

replies.author: Catox
replies.text:
I think it's related to the way those actions and collisions codes are executed consequently for each object : 
for each object :
- do the action => make it move
- check collision with wall => make them all change direction if there's one

From what I can see, it's very likely that those are performed starting with the last object (bottom down) down to the first.
So what happens is that they all move to the right until they nearly touch the wall.
At this point, the bottom right enemy object is moved to the right, so it touches the wall, therefore the direction is changed : they will all go to the left, but the last one is now slightly displaced.
Later when they are close to the left wall something equivalent happens : the whole bottom line is moved to the left, but the leftmost one happens to touch the whole, so everyone will then go right => the whole bottom line is then slightly displaced from the 2 others.
... and it goes on and the difference expands

That's most certainly solvable with some more or less advance algorithm, , but my post is already too long ^^

Or, of course, if they change the engine so that all actions are performed before or after any collision is ^^
